So as a kid, I was teased, for being effeminate,
for being gay… so a lot of my early life

was just denial about it, to myself and to
others… But starting probably around 16,

I realized that I liked guys.
Thanks so much for coming my name is Joel

Simkhai, the CEO and founder of Grindr.

We get together gay people in tech in LA
Unfortunately, here in the US it’s getting better, but we’re not quite there in terms of the equality front…

My story is the story of every gay man. That
we’re a hidden minority in some ways, and

always looking to meet. And the services out
there just weren’t great. I’m an introvert,

so I don’t do well at bars, I don’t do
very well at meeting someone right away. It's just not what I'm good at.
so online was my comfort zone.

Before the smartphone you’d
kind of have to stay home and be on the computer,

and I didn’t want that. I wanted something
that was more natural, more spontaneous and
I think that’s what we got with Grindr. Right now we are focused on who's around me...
Steve Jobs announced the second generation iPhone in June 2008,

and finally the technology
was there to allow it to happen. And I jumped

on it. Found some guys to help me. Build the
app and get it out there, and in March 2009,

we launched the app. Not much money, not much
of anything. No business plan.
Three months after we launched, Stephen Fry
mentioned us on Top Gear. And what is Grindr? It's basically a gay cruising application.
And that really blew us up. And to my surprise millions of men every day come on Grindr.
It's remarkable, really in my mind that it happened.
How many times was I on Grindr? Probably 8 or 9 times today. And I’ll probably go on a few more times.

The best part about my job is I don’t really
know what’s gonna happen. It’s going to

be a completely different day. We’ll see
what happens. We’ll rock on, and of course
we’ll GRIND on.
